AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Young trees have a smooth gray-brown bark, becoming deeply furrowed with long irregular plates or ridges with age. Highly variable.

The Sugar Maple is best known for it's autumn foliage show and sweet sap which is boiled down to make maple syrup. Anishinaabe oral tradition tells that the people learned to make maple sugar from the squirrels who in the hungry times of late winter would gnaw on Sugar Maple branches , returning the next day to lick up the sugar crystals that formed on the bark overnight. Freezing temperatures cause the water in the sap to sublimate, leaving a sweet crystalline crust like rock candy behind, enough to tide them over. This time is known as the "Maple Sugar Moon" or "Zizibaskwet Giizis," when stored food has dwindled and game is scace. Each tree yields between 5 and 60 gallons of sap per year; about 32 gallons of sap make 1 gallon of syrup.
yellowish-green, staminate or pistillate, 1/5 to 1/4" long
1-1/2" long paired samaras that make an acute angle or are almost parallel to one another.

Opposite, simple, 4-6" long, usually slightly wider than long. 5 lobes: 3 deeply divided and long pointed and 2 smaller ones toward base; slightly coarsely toothed with narrow and deep sinuses. Brilliant autumn color
Broad, five pointed lobed leaves, seedling's ability to survive deep understory shade
Apollo Sugar Maple, Acer saccharum 'Barrett Cole'

ThemeEntityData.Description: The Sugar Maple is best known for it's autumn foliage show and sweet sap which is boiled down to make maple syrup. Anishinaabe oral tradition tells that the people learned to make maple sugar from the squirrels who in the hungry times of late winter would gnaw on Sugar Maple branches , returning the next day to lick up the sugar crystals that formed on the bark overnight. Freezing temperatures cause the water in the sap to sublimate, leaving a sweet crystalline crust like rock candy behind, enough to tide them over. This time is known as the "Maple Sugar Moon" or "Zizibaskwet Giizis," when stored food has dwindled and game is scace. Each tree yields between 5 and 60 gallons of sap per year; about 32 gallons of sap make 1 gallon of syrup.
